text: Answer Question 1 (Section A) and three questions from Section B.
Section A carries 33% of the marks and Section B carries 67% of the marks for this paper.
You have 3 hours (plus any pre-agreed individual adjustment) to answer this paper.
Where appropriate (e.g. for formulae, equations, or diagrams) you may hand write or draw on the Inspera paper provided.
<strong>Candidates should not copy and paste figures or content from any other documents.</strong

sub-instructions: Answer all parts (a-o) of Question 1. Each part carries equal marks. Suggested total time: not more than 1 hour. As a guideline, we suggest average answers should be approximately 100 words long.
content: How does DNA exemplify the properties required of any molecule used to store genetic information in a biological system?
What is the anomeric carbon atom in polymers of D-glucose? Why is it important?
What are the properties of the transition-state complex of an enzyme-catalysed reaction?
Draw and annotate a diagram to explain the important features of an ion channel protein.
Briefly describe why fatty acids provide more energy per mole than glucose under oxidative conditions.
Describe three pieces of evidence for chemiosmosis.
Explain how experiments performed by Gregor Mendel refute each of the following assertions:
(i) in reproduction the male parent provides the information and the female the raw materials (Aristotle)
(ii) reproduction involves the irreversible mixing of characters from the two parents (Hippocrates).
Briefly describe the key elements of nucleotide excision repair.
What has changed in genome sequencing technologies since the human genome sequence was published? How is this impacting on the understanding of human biology?
What are Single Nucleotide Polymorphisms and how are they used to help characterize human disease?
How do viruses suppress the translation of host cell mRNAs and enable viral mRNAs to be translated instead?
How can a mutation in one of the two alleles of p53 contribute to an increased risk of cancer?
Describe the intracellular signalling pathway that occurs in the signal relay between Dictyostelium cells during aggregation.
Describe three changes that occur at the mid-blastula transition in a Xenopus embryo.
How are auxins transported in a developing plant embryo?

sub-instructions: Answer three questions from the following nine. All questions carry equal marks. Suggested total time for this section: 2 hours
content: Identify three distinct classes of RNA present in both eukaryotic and prokaryotic cells. Describe the role of each in protein synthesis.
It is estimated that half of a cellâ€™s ATP supply is used by the plasma membrane Na+-K+-ATPase or by the H+-ATPase. Discuss these proteins and their importance to cells.
Explain, with examples, the key mechanisms that allow photosynthetic organisms to convert light energy into ATP and NADPH.
How does organic nitrogen in a dead animal in the soil get converted to protein amino acids in living plants?
Discuss horizontal gene transfer in bacteria. Describe each of the three main mechanisms involved and how these processes have been important in recent bacterial evolution.
Discuss how DNA replication was shown to be both semi-conservative and semi- discontinuous.
How is genome-wide analysis of gene expression performed and how can it be used to improve our understanding of biology and disease?
Describe the intracellular signalling network that regulates the control of glycogen breakdown in mammalian muscle cells in response to adrenaline.
Using Drosophila as an example, discuss how experiments in model organisms have led to our current understanding of developmental biology?
